awd_titl_txt: Arabidopsis WWD2 and WDL Proteins Modulate Cell Expansion and Growth Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Principle Investigator: Patrick H. Masson	
NSF Proposal Number IOS-0821884
Title: Arabidopsis WVD2 and WDL Proteins Modulate Cell Expansion and Growth Behavior.
Abstract. Plant organs grow using a combination of localized cell divisions at apical structures called the meristems, and cell expansion in sub-apical regions. The patterns of cell division and cell expansion condition the morphology of these organs. Furthermore, regulated cell expansion in the elongation zones allows plant organs to develop directional growth responses to environmental stimuli and developmental cues, further contributing to plant morphogenesis and environmental adaptation. Regulated directionality (anisotropy) of cell expansion is critical, and intracellular microtubular polymers of a protein, called tubulin, which form a dense network underneath the plasma membrane, control this process by guiding the deposition of inextensible cellulose fibrils within the surrounding wall. The investigators have identified a group of 8 conserved plant-specific proteins that modulate the alignment of microtubules in expanding cells, thereby regulating the patterns of cell expansion and the growth behavior of the corresponding organs. They will use a combination of approaches derived from Genetics, Genomics, Cell Biology, Biochemistry and Physiology to establish the mode of action of these proteins, and investigate the regulation of their activity by plant hormones. This project is expected to have a profound impact on our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that govern anisotropic cell expansion and organs? growth behavior in plants, with potential impact on agriculture and biomass production for bioenergy conversion. A postdoctoral fellow will carry out the project, helped by undergraduate students who will be exposed to scientific experimentation and will be introduced to state-of-the-art technologies in the fields of Genetics, Genomics, Cell Biology and biomass production. Furthermore, an outreach program will be implemented whereby K-12 teachers will join the lab each summer of the project to work in partnership with the PI, the students and other lab members to design instructional materials for testing and implementation in K-12 classrooms and undergraduate lab courses.

por.por_cntn:
Our long-term research objectives are to understand the molecular mechanisms that govern root growth behavior in response to mechanical stimuli in their environment. It is important to better understand this biological process because it contributes to the environmental plasticity of the root system as it adapts to soils of different textures and/or physico-chemical properties, thereby conditioning plant survival, agricultural output under a variety of conditions, and biomass production in marginal lands. We are using the thale-cress plant (Arabidopsis thaliana) to better analyze these processes. Indeed, when forced to grow on tilted hard-agar surfaces, the roots of this plant display a well-characterized wavy and skewing growth behavior that derives from responses to gravity, touch and other surface-derived stimuli.

We previously identified mutations in Arabidopsis that affect root-growth behavior on hard surfaces in an attempt to characterize the molecular mechanisms that drive it. Characterization of some of these mutations revealed the role of a group of related and uncharacterized proteins in this process. Further investigations demonstrated that these proteins, called WVD2 and WDL1 through 7, modulate root growth behavior by altering the patterns of cell expansion in the growth zone. This process was also shown to be mediated by the cortical network of microtubules, an important component of the plant cytoskeleton, and a combination of in vitro and in vivo experiments suggested that the WVD2 and WDL proteins bind to these microtubules, probably modulating their dynamic properties and bundling.

Our research during this funding period has uncovered a possible interaction between the WVD2 / WDL proteins on the one hand, and the cytoplasmic domain of a plant hormone’s receptor that was previously implicated in the control of anisotropic cell expansion. Hence, this hormone might modulate anisotropic cell expansion and root growth behavior through a direct pathway involving WVD2, the WDL proteins, and the cortical microtubules while bypassing a need for differential gene expression.

While the genetic analysis used to identify the WVD2 and WDL proteins as modulators of root growth behavior and anisotropic cell expansion allowed us to uncover several regulators of this process, they also suffer from complications due to functional redundancy between genes encoding similar proteins, and from the possible early lethality associated with mutations in some of the genes involved. To overcome such problems, we investigated the possibility of using the natural variation that exists between Arabidopsis accessions isolated from different regions around the World, to identify more genes contributing to root-growth behavior on hard surfaces. We demonstrated a substantial variability in root-growth behavior between the 15 different accessions analyzed thus far. We then chose a couple of well-characterized accessions to identify new genes that contribute to the regulation of root skewing on hard surfaces. These loci will shed new light on the molecular mechanisms involved in this important process.

In addition to yielding new information on the molecular mechanisms that modulate root-growth behavior on hard surfaces, this project led to the training of three postdoctoral fellows, three graduate, six undergraduate and four high-school students, including two from underrepresented groups. Furthermore, materials derived from our research were incorporated in undergraduate- and graduate-level courses. Finally, a science teacher from Oneida-Nation High School joined our laboratory in the summers of 2008 and 2009 to learn more about root-growth behaviors and develop a high-school-level instructional module explaining plant growth responses to their environment.
